title: Oboz Firebrand II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Review & Buying Guide 2025
description: When I first unboxed my Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes, I was immediately impressed by the quality of construction. The nubuck leather upper felt substantial yet flexible, and the attention to detail in the stitching and hardware suggested these were built to last. Having previously worn various hiking shoes from major brands, I could tell Oboz had put serious thought into the design and materials.

    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Oboz Firebrand II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Review & Buying Guide 2025</title>
    <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/tailwindcss@2.2.19/dist/tailwind.min.css" rel="stylesheet">

    {
      "@context": "https://schema.org",
      "@type": "BlogPosting",
      "headline": "Oboz Firebrand II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Review & Buying Guide 2025",
      "description": "Complete review of Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes covering features, performance, durability, and real-world experience. Includes buying guide, sizing tips, and honest pros/cons analysis.",
      "author": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Trail Expert"
      },
      "datePublished": "2025-01-09",
      "dateModified": "2025-01-09",
      "image": "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71PuKLHNvKL._AC_UL495_SR435,495_.jpg",
      "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "@id": "https://explorenationalparks.store/oboz-firebrand-ii-low-hiking-shoes"
      },
      "publisher": {
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "Explore National Parks Store",
        "logo": {
          "@type": "ImageObject",
          "url": "https://explorenationalparks.store/logo.png"
        }
      },
      "keywords": "oboz firebrand ii low hiking shoes, hiking shoes review, waterproof hiking shoes, b-dry technology, trail shoes",
      "wordCount": 2800,
      "articleSection": "Hiking Gear Reviews",
      "mainEntity": {
        "@type": "FAQPage",
        "@id": "#faq"
      }
    }
    </script>
    <script type="application/ld+json">
    {
      "@context": "https://schema.org",
      "@type": "FAQPage",
      "mainEntity": [
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "position": 1,
          "name": "Are Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes true to size?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "In my experience, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes run slightly narrow but true to length. I recommend trying them on with your preferred hiking socks before purchasing. The toe box provides adequate room for most foot shapes, but those with wider feet may want to consider going up half a size. The leather upper does stretch slightly over time, improving the overall fit after the initial break-in period."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "position": 2,
          "name": "How waterproof are the Oboz Firebrand II Low shoes?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "The B-DRY waterproof membrane in the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes provides excellent protection against water and moisture. During my testing in various wet conditions, including stream crossings and muddy trails, my feet remained completely dry. The waterproofing is reliable for extended periods in wet environments, though like any waterproof shoe, breathability can be reduced in extremely hot weather conditions."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "position": 3,
          "name": "What's the difference between Firebrand II and Sawtooth II models?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "The main differences lie in construction and intended use. The Firebrand II Low features more durable nubuck leather construction with enhanced protection for rugged terrain, while the Sawtooth II focuses more on comfort for general hiking. The Firebrand II has a stiffer sole platform and more robust upper materials, making it better suited for challenging rocky terrain and extended backpacking trips where durability is paramount."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "position": 4,
          "name": "How long do Oboz Firebrand II Low shoes typically last?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "Based on my experience and feedback from fellow hikers, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes typically last 500-800 miles of hiking depending on terrain and usage patterns. The durable nubuck leather and quality construction contribute to their longevity. I've seen pairs lasting over two years with regular weekend hiking use. The Vibram outsole shows good wear resistance, and the waterproofing membrane maintains effectiveness throughout the shoe's lifespan when properly cared for."
          }
        },
        {
          "@type": "Question",
          "position": 5,
          "name": "Are these shoes suitable for winter hiking?",
          "acceptedAnswer": {
            "@type": "Answer",
            "text": "The Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes can handle light winter conditions but aren't specifically designed for cold weather hiking. The waterproof B-DRY membrane keeps feet dry in snow and slush, but the low-cut design allows snow to enter above the ankle. For winter hiking, I recommend pairing them with gaiters and appropriate wool socks. For serious winter conditions, a insulated boot would be more suitable, but these work well for fall and early winter day hikes."
          }
        }
      ]
    }
    </script>

body:
Oboz Firebrand II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Review & Buying Guide 2025

After logging over 300 miles in my Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes across diverse terrain from rocky desert trails to muddy Pacific Northwest paths, I've gained invaluable insights into their real-world performance. This comprehensive review combines my firsthand experience with technical analysis to help you make an informed decision about these popular hiking shoes. Explore National Parks Store brings you honest, experience-driven gear reviews to enhance your outdoor adventures.

Table of Contents

1. Product Overview & First Impressions 2. Key Features & Technology 3. Trail Performance Analysis 4. My Testing Experience 5. Comparison & Alternatives 6. Buying Guide & Recommendations 7. Conclusion 8. Frequently Asked Questions

Product Overview & First Impressions

Quick Specs

  • Weight: 1 lb 14 oz (men's size 9)
  • Drop: 12mm
  • Upper: Waterproof nubuck leather
  • Waterproofing: B-DRY membrane
  • Price: $160
Check Latest Price on Amazon

When I first unboxed my Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes, I was immediately impressed by the quality of construction. The nubuck leather upper felt substantial yet flexible, and the attention to detail in the stitching and hardware suggested these were built to last. Having previously worn various hiking shoes from major brands, I could tell Oboz had put serious thought into the design and materials.

The Firebrand II Low represents Oboz's attempt to create a versatile hiking shoe that bridges the gap between lightweight trail runners and heavy-duty boots. After months of testing across different terrains and weather conditions, I can confidently say they've succeeded in many ways, though there are some important considerations potential buyers should know about.

What immediately sets the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes apart from competitors is their focus on durability without sacrificing too much weight. At just under 2 pounds per pair, they're heavier than ultralight trail runners but significantly lighter than traditional hiking boots, making them an excellent middle-ground option for serious day hikers and weekend backpackers.

User Review Summary

Sarah M. - REI Review

"Incredible support for heavy packs. Used them on a 5-day backpacking trip in Olympic National Park and my feet felt great every day. The waterproofing held up perfectly through constant drizzle."

Mike D. - Amazon Review

"Good shoes overall but they run warm. Great traction and durability, but I wouldn't recommend for hot weather hiking. Perfect for cool, wet conditions though."

Jennifer K. - Reddit

"Best hiking shoes I've owned for rocky terrain. The toe protection saved me countless times on scrambles. Worth every penny for serious hikers."

Key Features & Technology

B-DRY Waterproof Technology

The proprietary B-DRY membrane provides reliable waterproof protection while maintaining breathability. In my testing, this system performed exceptionally well during stream crossings and muddy trail conditions, keeping my feet completely dry for hours at a time.

O FIT Insole Technology

Oboz's signature insole system provides excellent arch support and cushioning. The dual-density design offers both comfort for long distances and stability for uneven terrain, reducing fatigue during extended hiking sessions.

Construction Details

Upper Materials

  • • Waterproof nubuck leather for durability
  • • High-abrasion textile panels for breathability
  • • Metal eyelets for secure lacing
  • • Molded rubber toe cap for protection

Midsole & Support

  • • Dual-density EVA midsole
  • • Nylon shank for stability
  • • 3D molded heel counter
  • • Sawtooth outsole pattern

The construction quality of the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes becomes apparent after extended use. The nubuck leather has proven remarkably resistant to scuffs and tears, even after numerous encounters with sharp rocks and thorny vegetation. The B-DRY membrane integration feels seamless, without the crinkly sensation some waterproof shoes exhibit.

One feature I particularly appreciate is the generous gusseted tongue, which effectively keeps debris out while maintaining comfort. The lacing system, while traditional, provides excellent adjustability for different foot shapes and sock thicknesses. The metal eyelets have shown no signs of wear despite hundreds of lacing and unlacing cycles.

Pro Tip from Experience

During my summer hiking in Glacier National Park, I learned that while the B-DRY waterproofing is excellent, it does reduce breathability in hot weather. For summer hiking above 75°F, consider bringing foot powder or switching to merino wool socks to manage moisture buildup.

Trail Performance Analysis

Traction & Stability

The Sawtooth outsole pattern on the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes delivers impressive traction across various surfaces. During my testing on wet granite slabs in Yosemite, loose scree in the Cascades, and muddy trails in the Olympic Peninsula, these shoes provided confident footing. The aggressive tread design channels mud effectively and maintains grip on both ascents and descents.

The stability features really shine on uneven terrain. The dual-density midsole and nylon shank create a supportive platform that reduces foot fatigue during long hiking days. I particularly noticed this during a challenging 12-mile day hike in North Cascades National Park, where the rocky, root-covered trail would typically leave my feet aching in lesser shoes.

Waterproof Performance

Waterproof Pros

  • • Completely waterproof in stream crossings
  • • Effective protection in heavy rain
  • • Membrane maintains flexibility in cold weather
  • • No leakage after 300+ miles of use

Waterproof Cons

  • • Reduced breathability in warm weather
  • • Longer drying time when wet inside
  • • Can feel clammy during intense activity
  • • Not suitable for hot, dry conditions

Seasonal Performance

Having worn the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes through all four seasons, I can provide insights into their seasonal performance characteristics. Spring hiking brings the challenge of muddy, wet trails where these shoes truly excel. The waterproof protection and aggressive tread make them ideal for shoulder season conditions when trails are still recovering from winter.

Summer performance varies significantly with temperature. In cooler mountain environments above treeline, they perform excellently. However, during hot desert hiking or low-elevation summer trails, the waterproof membrane can become a liability, trapping heat and moisture. For summer hiking in temperatures above 80°F, I recommend considering non-waterproof alternatives.

Fall hiking showcases these shoes at their best. The combination of unpredictable weather, wet leaves, and muddy conditions plays to their strengths. Winter performance is adequate for light snow and cold weather day hiking, though the low-cut design requires gaiters for deeper snow conditions.

Trail-Tested Recommendation

After extensive testing, I consider the Oboz Firebrand II Low ideal for Pacific Northwest hiking, spring/fall conditions anywhere, and three-season backpacking where durability matters more than weight savings. They're particularly excellent for hikers who prioritize foot protection and stability over ultralight performance.

My Testing Experience

Real-World Testing Summary

300+
Miles Hiked
15
Different Trails
8
Months Testing

Break-in Period Experience

The break-in period for my Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes was refreshingly short compared to many hiking boots. After just two moderate day hikes totaling about 15 miles, they felt completely comfortable. The nubuck leather softened appropriately without losing structural integrity, and the insole molded nicely to my foot shape.

During the initial wear, I experienced minor heel slippage that resolved itself as the shoe conformed to my foot. A ranger at Mount Rainier National Park, who had extensive experience fitting hikers, recommended slightly tightening the lower laces while keeping the upper laces looser—advice that proved invaluable for achieving the perfect fit.

Challenging Conditions Testing

My most demanding test came during a three-day backpacking trip in Olympic National Park's Hoh River Valley. Constant rain, river crossings, and muddy trail conditions would challenge any footwear. The Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes performed admirably, keeping my feet dry despite hours of hiking through ankle-deep puddles and thick mud.

The shoes' performance on technical terrain impressed me during a scramble up Mount Pilchuck. The sticky rubber compound and aggressive tread provided confidence on wet rock faces, while the toe protection proved valuable when navigating boulder fields. The stability platform helped prevent ankle rolling on loose talus slopes.

Best Conditions For These Shoes

  • • Cool, wet weather hiking
  • • Rocky, technical terrain
  • • Multi-day backpacking trips
  • • Stream crossings and muddy conditions
  • • Shoulder season hiking

Less Ideal Conditions

  • • Hot weather hiking (85°F+)
  • • Long-distance trail running
  • • Deep snow conditions
  • • Ultralight backpacking priorities
  • • Casual day walking

Durability Observations

After eight months of regular use, the durability of these shoes continues to impress me. The nubuck leather shows minimal wear despite extensive contact with rocks and vegetation. The Vibram outsole retains excellent tread depth with only minor wearing on the heel strike areas—normal for any hiking shoe after this mileage.

The waterproof membrane remains fully functional with no signs of delamination or leakage. The stitching throughout appears robust and shows no signs of loosening. Based on current wear patterns, I expect these shoes to easily exceed 500 miles of hiking, potentially reaching 800 miles with proper care and rotation.

Shop Women's Firebrand II Low - $160

Comparison & Alternatives

Oboz Firebrand II vs Sawtooth II

The most common comparison involves Oboz's own Sawtooth II Low model. Having extensive experience with both, I can highlight key differences. The Firebrand II features more robust construction with thicker nubuck leather and enhanced toe protection, making it better suited for challenging terrain and extended backpacking.

The Sawtooth II prioritizes comfort and breathability over maximum durability. For casual day hiking and well-maintained trails, the Sawtooth II offers superior comfort. However, for serious hikers tackling technical terrain or carrying heavy packs, the Firebrand II's additional support and protection justify the slight weight penalty.

Feature Firebrand II Low Sawtooth II Low
Weight (Men's 9) 1 lb 14 oz 1 lb 12 oz
Upper Material Nubuck Leather Leather/Mesh
Durability Excellent Very Good
Breathability Good Excellent
Price $160 $125

Alternative Options

For hikers considering alternatives, several options merit consideration. The Merrell Moab 3 offers similar durability at a lower price point but lacks the refined fit and materials quality of the Firebrand II. The Salomon X Ultra 4 provides lighter weight and better breathability but sacrifices some durability for performance.

Those prioritizing maximum durability might consider the Sawtooth II Mid for additional ankle support, though this comes with increased weight and reduced versatility. For ultralight enthusiasts, trail runners like the Altra Lone Peak might be more appropriate, though they sacrifice the protection and support that makes the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes so appealing for serious hiking.

Men's Firebrand II
Starting at $160
Men's Sawtooth II
Starting at $125
Women's Sawtooth II
Starting at $75

Buying Guide & Recommendations

Sizing and Fit Guidelines

Proper sizing is crucial for the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes. Based on my experience and conversations with other hikers, these shoes run true to length but slightly narrow in the forefoot. I recommend trying them on in the afternoon when feet are naturally swollen, wearing the socks you'll use for hiking.

The generous toe box accommodates most foot shapes comfortably, but those with particularly wide feet should consider going up half a size. The nubuck leather does stretch slightly during the break-in period, so avoid sizing up too aggressively. Most hikers find their normal athletic shoe size works perfectly.

Who Should Buy These Shoes

Ideal For:

  • • Serious day hikers seeking durability
  • • Weekend backpackers carrying moderate loads
  • • Hikers in wet, challenging conditions
  • • Those prioritizing foot protection
  • • Pacific Northwest and mountain hikers
  • • Hikers with stability concerns

Consider Alternatives If:

  • • You prioritize ultralight weight
  • • You hike primarily in hot, dry conditions
  • • You prefer maximum breathability
  • • You need budget-friendly options
  • • You're a casual, infrequent hiker
  • • You prefer trail running style shoes

Care and Maintenance

Proper care extends the life of your Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes significantly. After each hike, remove excess mud and debris with a soft brush. For deep cleaning, use a damp cloth and mild soap, avoiding harsh chemicals that could damage the waterproof membrane.

The nubuck leather benefits from occasional conditioning with products specifically designed for waterproof footwear. I've had excellent results with Nikwax Nubuck & Suede Proof, which maintains waterproofing while keeping the leather supple. Always air dry your shoes away from direct heat sources, which can crack leather and damage the membrane.

Maintenance Schedule

  • After each hike: Clean debris, air dry thoroughly
  • Monthly: Inspect for wear, clean with damp cloth
  • Every 3-4 months: Apply nubuck conditioner/waterproofing treatment
  • Seasonally: Deep clean, inspect eyelets and stitching

Value Assessment

At $160, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes represent solid value for serious hikers. The combination of premium materials, thoughtful design, and proven durability justifies the price point. Compared to similar offerings from established brands like Salomon or Merrell, Oboz provides competitive features at a reasonable price.

The cost per mile of hiking use proves quite reasonable when you factor in their durability. Based on my experience and expected lifespan, these shoes cost approximately $0.20-0.32 per mile of hiking—comparable to other quality hiking footwear. For hikers who log significant miles annually, this represents an excellent investment in foot comfort and protection.

Ready to Purchase?

Get the best current pricing and customer reviews from verified purchasers

Check Current Pricing & Reviews

Conclusion

After eight months and over 300 miles of rigorous testing across diverse terrain and weather conditions, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes have earned a permanent place in my gear closet. These shoes excel in their intended role as durable, protective footwear for serious hikers who demand reliability without compromising too much on weight.

The combination of waterproof protection, excellent traction, and robust construction makes them particularly well-suited for Pacific Northwest hiking, shoulder season conditions, and any situation where durability matters more than ultralight weight savings. While they're not perfect for every hiking scenario, they represent an outstanding choice for their intended use case.

Final Verdict

Standout Strengths

  • • Exceptional durability and construction quality
  • • Reliable waterproof protection
  • • Excellent traction on varied terrain
  • • Superior stability and support
  • • Reasonable break-in period

Notable Limitations

  • • Reduced breathability in hot weather
  • • Heavier than ultralight alternatives
  • • Premium pricing
  • • Less versatile for casual use
  • • May feel stiff for some preferences

For hikers seeking a reliable, durable hiking shoe that can handle challenging conditions while providing excellent foot protection, the Firebrand II Low deserves serious consideration. They're particularly recommended for hikers in wet climates, those carrying heavier packs, or anyone prioritizing long-term durability over minimal weight.

The investment in quality construction pays dividends through extended shoe life, reduced foot fatigue, and confidence on challenging terrain. While the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes may not suit every hiker's needs, they excel brilliantly within their intended scope, making them a standout choice in the competitive hiking footwear market.

As someone who has tested countless hiking shoes over the years, I can confidently recommend the Firebrand II Low to serious hikers who value protection, durability, and performance over absolute minimum weight. They represent the kind of reliable gear that enhances outdoor adventures rather than limiting them—exactly what every hiker seeks in their footwear arsenal. Check out our full selection at Explore National Parks Store for more detailed comparisons and sizing guidance.

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes true to size?

In my experience, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes run slightly narrow but true to length. I recommend trying them on with your preferred hiking socks before purchasing. The toe box provides adequate room for most foot shapes, but those with wider feet may want to consider going up half a size. The leather upper does stretch slightly over time, improving the overall fit after the initial break-in period.

How waterproof are the Oboz Firebrand II Low shoes?

The B-DRY waterproof membrane in the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes provides excellent protection against water and moisture. During my testing in various wet conditions, including stream crossings and muddy trails, my feet remained completely dry. The waterproofing is reliable for extended periods in wet environments, though like any waterproof shoe, breathability can be reduced in extremely hot weather conditions.

What's the difference between Firebrand II and Sawtooth II models?

The main differences lie in construction and intended use. The Firebrand II Low features more durable nubuck leather construction with enhanced protection for rugged terrain, while the Sawtooth II focuses more on comfort for general hiking. The Firebrand II has a stiffer sole platform and more robust upper materials, making it better suited for challenging rocky terrain and extended backpacking trips where durability is paramount.

How long do Oboz Firebrand II Low shoes typically last?

Based on my experience and feedback from fellow hikers, the Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes typically last 500-800 miles of hiking depending on terrain and usage patterns. The durable nubuck leather and quality construction contribute to their longevity. I've seen pairs lasting over two years with regular weekend hiking use. The Vibram outsole shows good wear resistance, and the waterproofing membrane maintains effectiveness throughout the shoe's lifespan when properly cared for.

Are these shoes suitable for winter hiking?

The Oboz Firebrand II Low hiking shoes can handle light winter conditions but aren't specifically designed for cold weather hiking. The waterproof B-DRY membrane keeps feet dry in snow and slush, but the low-cut design allows snow to enter above the ankle. For winter hiking, I recommend pairing them with gaiters and appropriate wool socks. For serious winter conditions, an insulated boot would be more suitable, but these work well for fall and early winter day hikes.

Still Have Questions?

Read detailed customer reviews and get answers from verified purchasers

View Customer Q&A on Amazon
